title: Bromyard Downs Walking Route

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Track across Bromyard Downs
images.caption: Track across Bromyard Downs. Heading north across this large stretch of open access common. Hillfield Coppice on the right.

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Track across Bromyard Downs
images.caption: The tracks at the top of the downs provide extensive views in all directions as well as autumn colour. This one heads north and on the Horizon is Titterstone Clee Hill.

images.title: P L Chadwick / View across Bromyard Downs
images.caption: View across the downs. The 262 acres of open land known as the Bromyard Downs are ideal for walking and offer excellent views.

images.title: Whatlep / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Royal Oak public house - this conveniently located pub is a fine choice for some post walk refreshments

images.title: Trevor Rickard / Bromyard from Bromyard Downs
images.caption: Bromyard from Bromyard Downs. Looking westwards from this vantage point on the Downs provides a view of the whole town.

images.title: P L Chadwick / Bromyard Downs car park
images.caption: Car park. A few yards along the road from the Royal Oak public house and car park is this public car park for visitors to the Bromyard Downs.

images.title: Alan Rosevear / Old Toll House on Bromyard Downs
images.caption: Old Toll House on Bromyard Downs

description: This area of common land in Bromyard has some nice walking trails and a fine pub to visit. You can start the walk from the car park on the Downs at postcode HR7 4QP. It's located just to the north east of the town. From here you can pick up a series of trails taking you to gorse, grassland, woodland and coppice. It's great for flora and fauna with lovely wildflowers attracting various butterflies during the summer months. Birdlife includes cuckoo, bullfinch, marsh tit, lesser spotted and green woodpecker, woodcock, and stock dove. The Downs are also in an elevated postion, over 700 feet above sea level. As such there are fine views towards the Clee Hills from the high points. The area has an interesting history, having once been a race-course, a golf-course and even a rifle-range. Just to the east is the old railway line which ran from Worcester through to Leominster via Bromyard. In 2022 plans were announced to convert it into a shared cycling and walking route. You can walk along part of the line on the Bromyard Railway Walk which starts to the east of the town at Washcroft.
